planets.description: The smallest planet in our solar system and closest to the Sun. Mercury has extreme temperature variations and no atmosphere.
The hottest planet in our solar system with a thick, toxic atmosphere. Often called Earth's twin due to similar size.
The only known planet to harbor life. Earth has liquid water, a protective atmosphere, and a magnetic field.
Known for its reddish appearance due to iron oxide. Mars has the largest volcano and canyon in the solar system.
The largest planet in our solar system. Jupiter has a Great Red Spot storm and over 80 moons.
Famous for its prominent ring system. Saturn is less dense than water and has 146 known moons.
An ice giant that rotates on its side. Uranus has a faint ring system and 27 known moons.
The windiest planet with speeds up to 2,100 km/h. Neptune has 16 known moons including Triton.
The closest known exoplanet to Earth, located in the habitable zone of Proxima Centauri.
Often called Earth's cousin, this planet orbits in the habitable zone of a Sun-like star.
One of seven Earth-sized planets in the TRAPPIST-1 system, potentially habitable.
The first exoplanet discovered transiting its star, a hot Jupiter with an evaporating atmosphere.
A potentially habitable super-Earth in the Gliese 581 system.
The first Earth-size planet discovered in the habitable zone of another star.
A super-Earth possibly made of diamond, with surface temperatures over 2,000Â°C.
The first planet found in the habitable zone of a Sun-like star by the Kepler mission.
A super-Earth in the habitable zone of a red dwarf star in a triple star system.
One of the most Earth-like planets discovered, with 70% chance of being rocky.
A potentially habitable super-Earth orbiting within the habitable zone.
A sub-Neptune with water vapor detected in its atmosphere, potentially habitable.
A super-Earth in the habitable zone, one of the closest potentially habitable worlds.
A rocky super-Earth that may retain its atmosphere, making it potentially habitable.
A super-Earth with high potential for habitability, receiving similar energy as Earth.
An Earth-size planet in the habitable zone, very similar to Earth in size and temperature.
A temperate Earth-sized planet orbiting a quiet red dwarf star.
A super-Earth in the habitable zone of the nearby Sun-like star Tau Ceti.
The most Earth-like planet found, orbiting a Sun-like star in the habitable zone.
A hot Jupiter with water vapor in its atmosphere and extreme temperatures.
A hot Jupiter with clouds made of corundum, the mineral that forms rubies and sapphires.
The first confirmed circumbinary planet, orbiting two stars like Tatooine in Star Wars.
The darkest known planet, reflecting less than 1% of light that hits it.
A hot Jupiter being consumed by its host star, with a comet-like tail.
The first rocky planet discovered by Kepler, a lava world close to its star.
One of the first super-Earths discovered, likely covered in lava.
A Neptune-sized planet with a comet-like tail of hydrogen escaping its atmosphere.
One of the largest known planets, with extremely low density and retrograde orbit.
A deep blue hot Jupiter with glass rain and winds of 7,000 km/h.
An Earth-sized planet so close to its star that its surface is molten rock.
A hot Jupiter with clear skies and water vapor detected by James Webb Space Telescope.
Possibly the exposed core of a gas giant that lost its atmosphere.
The hottest known planet, hotter than most stars, with temperatures over 4,000Â°C.
One of the first exoplanets discovered, orbiting a pulsar in a deadly radiation environment.
The smallest known exoplanet, smaller than Mercury, likely airless and rocky.
An ultra-hot Jupiter with extreme temperatures and possible titanium oxide in its atmosphere.
A rocky planet about 80% the size of Earth in a nearby multi-planet system.
Part of a unique system where planets are in orbital resonance, like a cosmic symphony.
A hot Jupiter where it literally rains molten iron due to extreme temperatures.
A rocky planet with a magma ocean and rock vapor atmosphere on its day side.
A hot Jupiter stretched into an oval shape by its star's extreme gravitational forces.
A dense, iron-rich planet that completes an orbit around its star in just 7.7 hours.

starSystems.description: Our home star system containing the Sun and eight planets, along with numerous moons, asteroids, and comets.
The closest star system to Earth, consisting of three stars: Alpha Centauri A, B, and Proxima Centauri.
The brightest star in Earth's night sky, actually a binary star system with Sirius A and B.
One of the most luminous stars near Earth and the northern pole star around 12,000 BCE.
The brightest star in the northern celestial hemisphere and fourth-brightest in Earth's night sky.
Actually a complex multiple star system of four stars in two binary pairs.
A blue supergiant star and one of the most luminous stars known in the Milky Way.
The eighth-brightest star in Earth's night sky, part of a binary star system.
A red supergiant star that may explode as a supernova in the next 100,000 years.
One of the vertices of the Summer Triangle asterism, rotating very rapidly.
An ultra-cool dwarf star with seven Earth-sized planets, three potentially habitable.
A Sun-like star hosting Kepler-452b, often called Earth's cousin.
A red dwarf star with multiple planets, including potentially habitable worlds.
A binary star system with five known planets, including the diamond planet 55 Cancri e.
The first star known to have a transiting exoplanet, revolutionizing exoplanet detection.
One of the nearest stars to Earth, a red dwarf with frequent stellar flares.
The nearest single star to Earth and the star with the highest proper motion.
A Sun-like star with multiple planets, including potentially habitable super-Earths.
A young Sun-like star with a confirmed planet and debris disk.
A quiet red dwarf star hosting the temperate planet Ross 128 b.
